major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: EARTH 436A
EARTH 436A 001
View requirements for EARTH 436A

Thesis Course (Earth 436) provides an opportunity for students to design and conduct independent research under the supervision of a faculty member in the Department of Earth & Environmental Sciences.
In the past years, a number of excellent research projects have been completed leading in some cases to award winning presentations at conferences and publications in peer-reviewed journals.

Students must normally obtain a minimum mark of 75% in Earth 436A to be allowed to register in Earth 436B. For students who enroll in Earth 436A only, the scope of work will involve the selection of a scientific topic of interest, detailed review of several published papers on the subject and the development of a potential research project that would fill a gap in current knowledge on the subject.

In Earth 436B, the remaining activities required to complete the research project are carried out based on the experimental design formulated in Earth 436A. The format and structure of the Final Research Report can be either a conventional thesis document or a journal manuscript.

It involves oral communication either one on one or before groups both large and small and written communication, which involves preparation of maps, charts and 6 narrative reports with personal observations, analyses and reviews of your own new work and that of previous workers.

While most of your work will be technical and reflect scientific rigor, you may be called upon to prepare shorter status and policy briefs for decision-makers, legal summaries and commentaries, mine stakes and resource claim descriptions, and other items, all of which require organized and well-reasoned clear writing.

Students should familiar with and able to do the following at the end of this course: • plan and conduct independent and original research under the guidance of a research advisor • learn how to explore, organize, execute, share and disseminate the results of your own scientific questions and thoughts • acquire new practical research and analytical skills using data either collected by yourself in the field or assembled in the laboratory or information/data collected by someone else (often the faculty advisor) in a research environment that you would not have had a chance to do elsewhere in your program • learn discipline-specific protocols and procedures for addressing scientific questions and procedures and formats for reporting technical information according to discipline or subdiscipline standards • acquire an appreciation for and basic skill level to organize, interpret, and identify relevance of new information and research results • understand how to organize, communicate effectively and clearly disseminate new information to peers and other professionals, both written and orally • know how to undertake self-assessment, and learn how to give and receive constructive review and critique by your peers

Field trips: Four field trips will occur during lecture and lab session hours in September and early October.
The field trips are intended to give an overview of the glacial stratigraphy and sediment-landform assemblages in the region as well as some hands-on experience.

The second StoryMap will be about a specific map sheet area selected from a short list of available surficial geology maps produced by a government geological survey in recent years.

The StoryMap will provide an overview of the main geological and geomorphological features of the map, and will also put the map into the broader regional context based on the available scientific literature.

An introduction to processes and techniques for incorporating environmental considerations in planning and evaluating proposals for future undertakings that may have significant social and biophysical effects.

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.

interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);

topics: Notice of Recording
Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
Email: jen.nelson@uwaterloo.ca
Topics will be chosen from linear equations, systems of linear equations, linear inequalities, functions, set theory, permutations and combinations, binomial theorem, probability theory.
The course begins with a review of operations with real numbers and fundamental algebra skills.
The solutions of polynomial equations, both linear and quadratic, in one and two variables and their graphical representation are studied.
An extension is made to linear systems with their solutions being expressed both algebraically and graphically.
To solve linear systems, matrices and the associated row reduction strategies are used.
The relationship between exponential functions and logarithmic functions is examined.
The basic properties of logarithms are introduced and used to solve logarithmic and exponential equations.
Various applications involving exponential growth and decay and logarithmic scales are presented.
Concepts in set theory and counting theory support the study of probability theory.
Perform operations with real numbers and algebraic expressions.
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including those involving absolute value, and represent the solutions algebraically and graphically.
Solve a system of linear equations using matrix operations, introducing a free variable, or parameter as appropriate.
Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Recognize that the solutions to a quadratic equation in two variables lie on a curve known as a parabola and analyze the properties of a parabola.
Describe the relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function.
Use the properties of logarithms to solve logarithmic and exponential equations, and to solve problems involving exponential growth and decay, and logarithmic scales.
Use the appropriate symbols and language in set theory to perform set operations, represent sets and subsets using Venn diagrams, and apply the counting principles for sets in real-life situations.

course_name: MATH104 - Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
The major concepts introduced to solve problems are rate of change, optimization, growth and decay, and integration.
This course provides an introduction to the applications of differential and integral calculus in business, the behavioural sciences, and the social sciences.
A special type of limit will give rise to the derivative, the central idea in differential calculus.

The interpretation of the derivative in applications such as rates of change and optimization, where the situations can be modelled by algebraic, exponential, or logarithmic functions, will be examined.
The concepts of the antiderivative and the indefinite integral will be studied.
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus will relate the integral to the derivative.
The problem of calculating the area under a curve will lead to the definite integral, a basic concept of integral calculus.
The interpretation of the integral in various applications will be studied.

topics: Organismal and Evolutionary Ecology Fall 2023
Learn Discussion Board
Email and Appointment Requests

Coverage includes hypothesis testing and the nature of scientific inquiry, basic population genetics, physiological ecology, life histories, dispersal, basic population and community ecology, macroevolution, systematics and classification, as well as functional morphology.
The theory of evolution unites the whole of biology and all living organisms into a coherent body of knowledge, allowing comparisons across all forms of life.
Ecology describes how organisms interact with their environment and each other to create interdependent systems from microscopic to global scales.

These disciplines are fundamentally tied together: evolution is the primary mechanism by which species adapt to their environment; ecological interactions and environmental variability drive natural selection.

You will also carry out simulated lab assignments to test the principles of evolution, design ecological experiments to test alternate hypotheses about the conservation of species and manipulate demographic parameters to test their influence on population growth.

Define ecological and evolutionary terms, such as the niche, adaptation, and altruism
Illustrate these mechanisms in the context of course examples
Explain how ecological interactions and evolution are interconnected

Introduction to the biology of bacterial and archaeal organisms.
Topics include cell structure and function, methods of cultivation, genetics, phylogeny and taxonomy, and metabolic and genetic diversity.

The knowledge gained in this course will also prepare you to succeed in more advanced courses in microbiology, microbial ecology, and molecular biology.
Explain the impact of microbiology on the evolution of life and on human society.

List nutritional categories of microbial metabolism and identify appropriate methods for cultivating microorganisms from these categories.
Explain how microorganisms regulate gene expression in order to compete for limited energy and nutrients.
List methods and mechanisms for exchange and manipulation of microbial DNA.
Describe how modern molecular methods have impacted microbiology.

topics: Ecosystem Ecology Fall 2024
This course provides an overview of the dynamic interactions among microbes, plants, animals, and their physical environment with emphasis on ecosystem structure and function.

Topics explored through lectures and tutorial sessions include the hydrological cycle, biogeochemical cycling, ecological energetics, roles of population and community interactions, paleoecology, and current topics in ecosystem science.
An ecosystem is defined as an integrated system of interacting biotic and abiotic components that occupy a volume of space.
Consequently, society needs well trained people with skills in ecosystem science to effectively protect and manage ecosystems in the face of ever-growing pressures.
Both theoretical and applied aspects of ecosystem ecology will be discussed.

The synchronous (scheduled) in-person tutorials and associated assignments will provide experiential learning of relevant skills in generation and interpretation of data, integration of concepts, critical analysis, and written and oral communication.
Define and explain, in written and oral presentations, the main terms and concepts in ecosystem ecology, such as energy flow and nutrient cycling.
Explain how interactions between organisms and the environment regulate the structure and function of ecosystems.
Generate, analyze and interpret data on nutrient limitation, nutrient cycling and food-web interactions, and communicate the findings and their importance in written reports.
Use basic principles of ecosystem science to anticipate how ecosystems and their components will likely respond to changes in physical, chemical and biological conditions.
Critically analyze published research papers in ecosystem ecology.

topics: General Chemistry 1 Winter 2025
RCH 101
The stoichiometry of compounds and chemical reactions.
Energy changes in chemical systems.
Electronic structure of atoms and molecules; correlation with the chemical reactivity of common elements, inorganic and organic compounds.
The second part of this course is concerned with explaining periodicity and trends in chemical reactivity in terms of the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

Topics covered in this part of the course include the quantum theory of the hydrogen atom; electron configurations in multi-electron atoms; ionic and covalent bonding; Lewis structures, valence shell electron repulsion theory and molecular geometry; quantum mechanical bonding theories, including valence bond theory and molecular orbital theory.
Additional topics may include an introduction to electron-transfer reactions, including the assignment of oxidation states and the balancing of oxidation-reduction reactions.
assess the greenness of a chemical reaction using Atom Economy and E-Factor metrics.
describe the electronic structure of atoms in terms of quantum theory using atomic orbitals and quantum numbers.
justify the organization of the periodic table and predict trends in the properties of the elements.
describe bonding in molecules in terms of atomic orbitals and molecular orbitals, and explain molecular shape and stability in terms of electron count.
describe the interactions of molecules in solids, liquids, and gases to compare physical and reactive properties.

Philosophy of Teaching

Dr. Rosamond's teaching philosophy focuses on (a) active learning techniques, including field and laboratory experience, and practical demonstrations in class, (b) building on the mathematical and chemical fundamentals in Earth Sciences.
She is interested in adapting curricula to include experiential learning, focus on students' analytical skills, and to scaffold skills and concepts across courses in Earth & Environmental Sciences.

Laboratory sessions will involve various activities related to acid-base equilibrium, redox reactions, chemical modeling, and analytical instrumentation methods.
Thermodynamics offers Geoscientists a powerful tool to aid in the interpretation of near surface processes.

It can be used to delineate the physicochemical conditions that led to a particular mineral assemblage; to discern whether a mineral assemblage could have resulted from equilibrium or disequilibrium (kinetic-controlled) conditions; to aid in decision-making in exploration geochemistry; and to design geochemical barriers and containment systems at waste disposal sites.
Applications include geothermal systems, acid-mine drainage, carbon sequestration, and other near surface environmental systems.

Understand the concepts of chemical equilibrium and metastability in the context of Earth systems

View requirements for EARTH 458L
Applied geophysics provides geoscientists with a wide-range of non-invasive methods for characterizing the Earth's interior.

This course is an introduction to the physical principles underlying field acquisition, processing, and data interpretation for commonly used applied geophysical techniques (seismic, electrical, electromagnetic induction, gravity, and magnetic methods).

This course is not only pertinent for geoscientists but also for engineers and others interested in learning how physics can be used to explore the Earth's interior or perform non-destructive testing.
Near-surface geophysics is used to characterize the shallow subsurface for a wide-spectrum of applications.
This application-oriented course covers current methodology in near-surface geophysics, including electrical, electromagnetic, ground penetrating radar, seismic refraction, and well-logging methods.
Techniques for geophysical data acquisition and interpretation are studied and applied to field data.
Examples of the application of geophysical techniques to archeological, forensics, geotechnical, glaciology, and hydrogeological problems are examined.
View requirements for EARTH 461
A field-oriented course on current methodology in the general area of geotechnical or engineering geophysics as applied to environmental problems.

Typical topics covered: well logging and time domain electromagnetic surveys for groundwater supply; magnetic and terrain conductivity surveys for waste materials; ground penetrating radar applications to stratigraphy and contamination; streaming potential surveys of dam leakage.

topics: RCH 211
Emphasis on concepts related to fluvial processes, river mechanics, the relationship between environmental change and river regime.
Fluvial geomorphology is the scientific study of river landforms and the processes that create them.

A working knowledge of fluvial processes has important practical environmental science, watershed management and engineering applications and is relevant to many other fields of environmental enquiry such as environmental engineering, watershed planning, source water protection, forestry, and risk management.
This course will examine a range of physical and chemical processes that create micro and macro-scale landforms over a range of spatial and temporal scales.
Implications of these processes for environmental management in the context of environmental change will be considered.
To understand basic fluvial geomorphic processes and their role in landform development and change

merrin.macrae@uwaterloo.ca

This course focuses on ecological and biogeochemical processes that are linked to the terrestrial hydrological cycle and how these relate to the management of natural resources.

The objectives of this interdisciplinary course are to explore topics that integrate ecosystem processes with physical hydrology and examine the impacts of human activities on ecohydrological and hydrochemical processes within terrestrial systems.
Understand linkages between hydrological and biogeochemical processes in the natural environment
Understand the implications of land use change and climate change on selected ecosystems
Analyze and visualize numerical data and write laboratory reports
Jan. 14 Watershed Hydrology Field and Lab Methods for Water Quality 1 *Safety/services & orientation of labs; TAs do overview of labs
Feb. 25 Wetlands and In-stream Processes  *Data Lab Part 2

Each lab section will attend a total of two “practical labs” – one will be held outdoors in the field and the other will be held indoors in a laboratory setting.
For the indoor lab, students will learn standard techniques for the processing of samples and the analyses of key water quality parameters.
This time of year can be cold and wet – students must have proper clothing to stay warm and dry for 1.5 hours in the field.
The meticulous construction of lab reports or field reports is a hallmark of any undergraduate education in geography and environmental sciences.
The careful analysis of hydrological and water quality data is also critical in water quality research and is a skill necessary to succeed in jobs in this field.

These labs will introduce you to the exploration and analysis of standard parameters in water quality analysis, by working with the data and constructing informative tables and graphs and describing what your data is showing you.
The exam will consist of a series of multiple choice, short answer and longer essay-style questions.

This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as understanding the importance of proper data collection and analysis, as well as the interpretation of these data.

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Water Science Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Methods of Aquatic Ecology Fall 2024

As an active researcher in aquatic ecology for more than 30 years (with the Fisheries and Oceans Canada, Environment Canada, Canadian Water Network and the University of Waterloo) the instructor (Prof. Mark Servos) will highlight and demonstrate some key techniques and share experiences based on extensive field work in Canada and elsewhere.
Professor Mark Servos
An introduction to methods used to sample and characterize the ecological structure and function of aquatic ecosystems, including basic aspects of the abiotic environment.
Field trips to lake and stream sites are combined with laboratory analysis of samples and data.
While the main emphasis is on the techniques, the exercises also provide direct experience with some of the natural and anthropogenic variation observable in aquatic systems.
On-line background with readings and assignments,
Field collections/demonstrations,
Sample preparation, analysis and demonstrations,
The impact of Belwood Lake on the ecology of the Grand River below the Shand Dam is used as a case study.
Students will develop an understanding of the common methods used in aquatic ecology to study and assess biodiversity and change in aquatic ecosystems.
It should be noted that the intention is not to cover every aspect of aquatic ecology but to apply methods and techniques that are common in current biomonitoring program.
Identify and use common sampling equipment applied in aquatic ecology,
Understand the physical and ecological structure and processes of a lake environment,
Understand the physical and ecological structure of a stream environment,
Put the ecological data collected into the context of the physical/biological environment,
Field Trip/Lab
Adaptation to Rivers
Data Analysis and Review
Practical Test and Data Analysis
Freshwater Ecology: Concepts and Environmental Applications in Limnology, 3rd Edition, 2020.
The assignments are all linked to the final interpretation and synthesis of the field sampling data and preparation of the final report.
The first assignments focus on field sampling methods (supporting the field trips) and then analysis of the samples collected and data interpretation.

The Introduction to Rock Mechanics course will repeatedly emphasize to the student the importance of understanding limitations and risks that must be managed in a Professional context, including issues such as responsibilities and ethics in design and reporting (Read the additional document on Information Sources and Ethics)
The design process in Geomechanics will be outlined as a process of risk management and continual design and project outcomes improvement
The student will learn to appreciate the importance of Earth Stresses and how to measure or estimate them, and be able to do depth and stress-pressure calculations

It is an expectation that the student knows what deformation-based design is and how to estimate and measure the deformability of rock at all scales from the laboratory to the field, for Civil, Mining and Petroleum Engineering applications, including foundations design, prediction compaction behavior

A basic comprehension of Yield and “Failure” of rock specimens and rock masses, including failure mechanisms, the yield behavior of joints, dilation, Mohr-Coulomb yield criteria, ultimate strength, use of Mohr-Coulomb diagrams to evaluate strength and proximity to strain-weakening yield, is expected as part of the design environment in rock mechanics
What is rheological modelling and its role in breaking down complex stress-strain-yield constitutive behavior into simpler elements to help understand the elements of constitutive laws and physics?
What are the basic mechanics and physics of creep in rock and rock masses (with some emphasis on salt mechanics)?

Doing slope stability analysis using limiting equilibrium of forces methods, including understanding how to incorporate forces arising from pore pressures, earthquake loading, self-weight, tensioned cables, and other factors into slope stability assessment.
Introduction to stress concentrations arising around circular openings and other structures in RM, using the Kirsch equations for stresses around a circular borehole.
Students are introduced to this analysis for first-order estimates of borehole yield, and sequenced/observational methods for tunneling in naturally jointed rock masses are introduced.
Calculating effective stress changes and proximity to strain-weakening yield based on stress and yield criterion analysis

Although the course does not involve mathematical modeling (numerical simulation) directly, everyone in RM areas and other engineering domains will be using numerical modeling approaches in their careers.
The concept of THMC coupling will be introduced

For example, shale gas and shale oil geoengineering, CO2 sequestration, and geothermal energy are important emerging areas that are rich in RM issues

course_name: EARTH439 - Flow and Transport Through Fractured Rocks (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Sciences - Water Science Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Email:

Fractures are ubiquitous in geologic media and important in disciplines such as physical and contaminant hydrogeology, geotechnical engineering, civil and environmental engineering, and petroleum engineering among other areas.
Despite the importance of fractures, its characterization and predictions of groundwater flow and contaminant transport are fraught with significant difficulties.
An introduction to the physical hydrogeology of fractured rock.

Topics will include a review of the structural geology of fractured rocks, development and validity of the cubic law, groundwater flow and contaminant transport in discrete fractures and fracture networks, hydraulic testing methods and the hydrogeology of low-permeability environments.
The overall aim for this course is for students to better understand concepts/processes that affect fluid flow and solute transport processes in fractured geologic media.
This includes the proper formulation of conceptual models, its proper translation to mathematical models and to obtain some knowledge on solution techniques to obtain quantitative solutions.
Week No. 6: Analysis of single-hole hydraulic tests in fractured rocks and its implications (Feb. 12), Review (Feb. 14)

topics: This course reviews the physical and chemical processes, environmental assessment techniques and best management practices related to stormwater management in the urban systems.
Stormwater management is an evolving field of study that includes aspects of environmental design, engineering, chemistry, hydrology, planning, finance, and public administration.

This course reviews the principles of urban stormwater management to provide a practical understanding of the development and implementation of effective management plans to mitigate environmental impacts of stormwater in urban environments.
Current design principles and their implementation in modern planning practices for stormwater management in urban watersheds are reviewed.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Field Ecology Winter 2025
**We aim to respond to forum posts and necessary emails within general workday hours (8:30 AM – 4:30 PM) and within 24hrs, except over weekends and holidays.

Introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
View requirements for ENVS 200

Such knowledge, called ecoliteracy, will provide a critical basis for your engagement in the 21st century, the “century of the environment”—not least because so many of the environmental issues we face derive in part from a limited understanding of how we are embedded within and dependent upon ecological systems.

Field ecology necessarily harbours an ethical component both because of our natural affinity for life (or ‘biophilia’) and because questions of ecological ‘impact’ and 'quality’ are necessarily value-laden.

In summary, this course introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
By the end of this course, you should be on a path to life-long learning as an ecologically-literate citizen.
Demonstrate how these principles apply to real-world situations (in context of lab activities, assignments, and labs), including human interactions with the natural world.
Articulate the elements of scientific inquiry as they apply to ecology/

These course learning outcomes will not only prepare you to be an informed citizen and member of the community of life on earth, but also provide the basis for knowledge, humility, and wisdom in your dealings with ecological problems in your daily life and eventual career.

topics: Dr. Richard Petrone                                                                                       Winter 2025
Lab Co-ordinator:
TBA
An introduction to the fundamental processes governing climate and hydrological systems and the links between them.
It starts with a discussion of basic atmospheric and hydrological processes and traces the flow of energy and water between the earth's surface and the atmosphere.
This course provides students with a thorough background of the fundamental processes governing the climate and hydrological systems, and the links between them.
The course first reviews fundamental atmospheric and hydrologic processes, and traces the flow of energy and water between the Earth’s surface and the atmosphere.
Through the use of group activities students will be given the opportunity to gain experience manipulating real hydrological and meteorological data and instrumentation.

This course will serve as an introduction to near-surface hydroclimatic processes, their feedbacks and climate change, forming essential background for upper level courses in climate change, hydroclimatology and environmental sciences and studies in general.
The fundamental knowledge and skills developed in this course will provide students with the basis to appreciate and understand the natural hydrologic and climate systems.
It also provides the required foundation for advanced courses in climatology and hydrology.

The objective of this course is to provide students with the background to further their interests in weather and climate, and provide the theoretical foundations for upper level science and management courses.
To identify the key boundary layer processes that drive the hydroclimate system.
To identify and evaluate the characteristics of different land-use types and ecosystems that drive their hydroclimatic regimes.

course_name: GEOG306 - Human Dimensions of Natural Hazards (0.50)
major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Human Dimensions of Natural Hazards - GEOG 306 Winter 2025
E. Mohammadi
E-mail:            elham.mohammadi@uwaterloo.ca

The physical nature of a wide range of geophysical and biophysical hazards will be explored, paying particular attention to the ways in which hazards become dangerous to humans, and the pathways by which humans can either increase or decrease their vulnerability in the face of natural hazards.
Natural hazards and associated disasters are, in part, a product of inappropriate human modifications or management of the natural landscape.
Throughout the course, case studies and examples drawn from countries and regions around the world will be used to clarify conceptual and methodological issues.
Appreciate the physical processes associated with various natural hazards, with a focus on geophysical, meteorological, and hydrological hazards.
Appreciate the key components of preparing for disasters.
Apply knowledge to compare hazards theory with real-world case studies.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Notice of Recording
Spatial Analysis Winter 2025
Email:                     dtrobins@uwaterloo.ca
Email:                      lqzhao@uwaterloo.ca
Advanced quantitative analysis in a spatial context.
Today, spatial analysis is mainly based on statistical techniques and geoprocessing using geographic information systems (GIS).

The spatial character of data implies several methodological challenges in spatial data analysis especially related to the spatial dependence of the data, which often invalidates non-spatial modeling and evaluation approaches and leads to special techniques for spatial sampling and spatial regression modeling.
In addition, selected topics such as spatial data mining and spatial analysis software may be addressed, depending upon the progress of the course.
Several real-world applications of spatial analysis techniques will be discussed and provide context for course assignments.
develop a general understanding of a variety of spatial modelling techniques
interpret and critically discuss spatial models and their results
The lecture will be used to introduce the theory and concepts behind spatial analysis methods as well as to demonstrate techniques that will aid the completion of lab assignments.
1  Jan 8 Introduction to Spatial Analysis 1, 2
Feb 12 Describing and Analyzing Fields 9
7  Feb 26 Describing and Analyzing Fields  9, 10
10  Mar 19 Landscape Metrics and Applications of Spatial Analysis
Spatial Data Analysis: an Introduction for GIS Users.
Principles of Geographical Information Systems.

Assignments commence in the second week of the course but the first week will require students to setup a workflow for using Jupyter Notebooks on the Math Faculty Jupyter Hub, which can be found here: https://jupyter.math.uwaterloo.ca/hub/login
There are no serious programming requirements or extensive prior knowledge of geographic information systems to complete the assignments in this course.

The notebooks will guide you through the technical steps and students will adjust notebook content/code to improve their understanding about the statistical and spatial analysis concepts discussed in the course.

course_name: GEOG368 - Ecology and Conservation for Planning (0.50)
major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Ecology and Conservation for Planning Winter 2025
This course provides students with a critical understanding of the relationship between human development and natural environments.
Students will develop an understanding of core ecological principles and how these can be taken up in plans and policies to promote nature conservation in urban and rural environments.

The course will include examples of how planners mitigate the environmental impacts of development of land, allotment of open space and parks, and conservation of sensitive areas and species in both urban and rural contexts.

topics: This course provides students with a foundation in the fundamentals of multivariate analysis, and practical experience of applying those techniques to problems in the geographical and environmental sciences.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Notice of Recording
Spatial Analysis Winter 2025
Email:                     dtrobins@uwaterloo.ca
Email:                      lqzhao@uwaterloo.ca
Advanced quantitative analysis in a spatial context.
Today, spatial analysis is mainly based on statistical techniques and geoprocessing using geographic information systems (GIS).

The spatial character of data implies several methodological challenges in spatial data analysis especially related to the spatial dependence of the data, which often invalidates non-spatial modeling and evaluation approaches and leads to special techniques for spatial sampling and spatial regression modeling.
In addition, selected topics such as spatial data mining and spatial analysis software may be addressed, depending upon the progress of the course.
Several real-world applications of spatial analysis techniques will be discussed and provide context for course assignments.
develop a general understanding of a variety of spatial modelling techniques
interpret and critically discuss spatial models and their results
The lecture will be used to introduce the theory and concepts behind spatial analysis methods as well as to demonstrate techniques that will aid the completion of lab assignments.
1  Jan 8 Introduction to Spatial Analysis 1, 2
Feb 12 Describing and Analyzing Fields 9
7  Feb 26 Describing and Analyzing Fields  9, 10
10  Mar 19 Landscape Metrics and Applications of Spatial Analysis
Spatial Data Analysis: an Introduction for GIS Users.
Principles of Geographical Information Systems.

Assignments commence in the second week of the course but the first week will require students to setup a workflow for using Jupyter Notebooks on the Math Faculty Jupyter Hub, which can be found here: https://jupyter.math.uwaterloo.ca/hub/login
There are no serious programming requirements or extensive prior knowledge of geographic information systems to complete the assignments in this course.

The notebooks will guide you through the technical steps and students will adjust notebook content/code to improve their understanding about the statistical and spatial analysis concepts discussed in the course.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: This course reviews the physical and chemical processes, environmental assessment techniques and best management practices related to stormwater management in the urban systems.
Stormwater management is an evolving field of study that includes aspects of environmental design, engineering, chemistry, hydrology, planning, finance, and public administration.

This course reviews the principles of urban stormwater management to provide a practical understanding of the development and implementation of effective management plans to mitigate environmental impacts of stormwater in urban environments.
Current design principles and their implementation in modern planning practices for stormwater management in urban watersheds are reviewed.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Soil Ecosystem Dynamics Fall 2024
Office Hours Appointment/walk-in

This course examines the role of soil in the environment, its importance as a natural resource in agricultural and forest productivity, and the effects on soil resources as a result of different management practices.

It is divided into three sections: 1) introduction to soil composition, formation, and physical, chemical and biological characteristics of soil; 2) soil degradation and management approaches to rehabilitation; 3) soil pollution and the role of soil in maintaining environmental integrity.
View requirements for ERS 484

Describe different systems of soil classification
Degraded Soils & Management

Soil Pollution & Environmental Integrity
Show how soil and soil pollution can influence atmospheric and hydrologic processes

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: RCH 211
Emphasis on concepts related to fluvial processes, river mechanics, the relationship between environmental change and river regime.
Fluvial geomorphology is the scientific study of river landforms and the processes that create them.

A working knowledge of fluvial processes has important practical environmental science, watershed management and engineering applications and is relevant to many other fields of environmental enquiry such as environmental engineering, watershed planning, source water protection, forestry, and risk management.
This course will examine a range of physical and chemical processes that create micro and macro-scale landforms over a range of spatial and temporal scales.
Implications of these processes for environmental management in the context of environmental change will be considered.
To understand basic fluvial geomorphic processes and their role in landform development and change

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: This course provides a comprehensive overview of the cryosphere and cryosphere-atmosphere interactions.

Topics covered include the material and thermodynamic properties of snow and ice, the role of the cryosphere in weather and climate, and the response of the cryosphere to climate change (past, present, and future).
Describe the fundamental material properties of snow and ice, including crystal structures, phase transitions, and thermodynamic behavior, and relate these properties to cryospheric processes.
Explain the role of the various elements of the cryosphere in weather and climate.
Explain the response of the various elements of the cryosphere to changing weather and climate.

Explain the impacts of climate change on the cryosphere, both in terms of observed trends and projected future changes, considering the implications for sea level rise, freshwater resources, and polar ecosystems.
Identify historical and state-of-the-art datasets, including field observations and remote sensing data, needed to document the current state of the cryosphere.
Identify field instruments for measuring cryospheric parameters, such as snow depth, ice thickness, and permafrost temperature.
Conduct basic simulations with cryosphere process models, such as snow and lake ice models.
Synthesize complex cryospheric data and model outputs to assess the broader implications for climate science, global carbon cycling, and human societies.
Communicate research findings and insights related to the cryosphere effectively through written reports and oral presentations.
Introduction to the Cryosphere
Material Properties of Snow and Ice
Analysis and interpretation of field-based measurements
Snow and Ice Thermodynamics
Analysis and interpretation of field-based measurements
Glaciers and Ice Sheets
Deadlines for each deliverable can be found in the course schedule above.

The term paper involves the completion of an extensive survey of the scientific literature on a relevant topic (e.g. remote sensing, numerical modeling or in-situ studies of any element of the cryosphere; cryosphere-climate interactions on a variety of space and time scales; the representation of elements of the cryosphere in climate or weather prediction models; the impact of changes in any element or a group of elements of the cryosphere on Society).
